intro: Hesperis lasiocarpa, commonly known as the woolly bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with similar floral structures. The plant is characterized by its hairy, grayish stems and clusters of pink or purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine, soft hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Hesperis lasiocarpa is often found in rocky or alpine habitats, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun.
